{{Infobox person | name = Kate O'Mara | image = | birth_name = Frances M. Carroll | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1939|8|10|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Leicester]], [[England]], UK | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Actress | spouse = Jeremy Young (1961â1976)
Richard Willis (1993â1996) | children = 2 sons}} '''Kate O'Mara''' (born 10 August 1939, [[Leicester]]) is an English film, stage and television actress. She is perhaps most widely known for her role as [[Caress Morell]], the scheming sister of [[Alexis Colby]] in the 1980s [[United States|American]] primetime soap opera ''[[Dynasty (TV series)|Dynasty]]'', though is also known for playing other villains such as [[Rani (Doctor Who)|The Rani]] in ''[[Doctor Who]]'' and Laura Wilde in ''[[Howards' Way]]''. ==Personal life== Born as Frances M. Carroll, the daughter of John F. Carroll and actress Hazel Bainbridge (b. 1909/1910 â d. 7 January 1998). Her younger sister is actress [[Belinda Carroll]].Birth registration info from [http://www.findmypast.co.uk Findmypast.co.uk]:
Civil Registration event: Birth
Name: CARROLL, Frances M
Registration District: Leicester
County: Leicestershire
Year of Registration: 1939
Quarter of Registration: Oct-Nov-Dec
Mother's Maiden Name: Bainbridge
Volume No: 7A, Page No: 592 After boarding school she attended Art school before becoming a full-time actress.[http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/features/Shes-not-a-superbitch-after.2321366.jp "She's not a superbitch after all"], ''Edinburgh Evening News''. 25 April 2002 She had an out of wedlock son, Chris Linde, whom she was forced to give up for adoption but was later reunited with him. She also had a second son, Dickon Young. She has been married and divorced three times. She is a strict vegetarian and animal rights activist.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-299154/The-shape-Im-Kate-OMara.html "The shape I'm in: Kate O'Mara"], ''Daily Mail''. Retrieved on 9 July 2010 ==Career== O'Mara made her stage debut in a production of ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' in 1963. Her earliest television appearances included guest roles on ''[[Danger Man]]'', ''[[Adam Adamant Lives!]]'', ''[[The Saint (TV series)|The Saint]]'', ''[[Z-Cars]]'' and ''[[The Avengers (TV series)|The Avengers]]'' in the 1960s. In 1970, she appeared in two [[Hammer Film Productions|Hammer Studio]] horror films; ''[[The Vampire Lovers]]'' and ''[[The Horror of Frankenstein]]''. In 1975, she had a regular role in the BBC drama series ''[[The Brothers (1972 TV series)|The Brothers]]''. In the early 1980s, O'Mara starred in the BBC soap opera ''[[Triangle (TV series)|Triangle]]''. In 1985, she played The Rani in the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' adventure "[[The Mark of the Rani]]". In 1986, she was cast as Caress Morrell in the American primetime soap opera ''Dynasty''.[http://www.metro.co.uk/showbiz/interviews/1120-kate-omara Kate O'Mara (interview)] Metro. 31 January 2005 Playing the sister of Alexis Colby ([[Joan Collins]]), O'Mara appeared in 17 episodes of the sixth season and 4 episodes of the seventh. After returning to the UK, she appeared in her second ''Doctor Who'' story, "[[Time and the Rani]]" in 1987. She was then later cast as another scheming villain, Laura Wilde, in the BBC soap ''[[Howards' Way]]'' in 1989. O'Mara continued to make television appearances throughout the 1990s, including ''[[Cluedo (UK game show)|Cluedo]]'' and ''[[Absolutely Fabulous]]''. In 2001, she had a recurring role in the [[ITV]] prison drama series ''[[Bad Girls (TV series)|Bad Girls]]'' before appearing in the short-lived revival of the soap opera ''[[Crossroads (soap opera)|Crossroads]]''. She has continued to perform on stage and in March 2008 she played [[Marlene Dietrich]] in a stage play entitled ''[[Lunch with Marlene]]''. From August to November 2008, she played Mrs Cheveley in [[Oscar Wilde|Oscar Wilde's]] stage play '[[An Ideal Husband]]' directed by [[Peter Hall (theatre director)|Peter Hall]] and produced by [[Bill Kenwright]]. {{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} O'Mara has also performed in radio and audio plays. In 2000 she reprised her role as the Rani in the [[BBV]] audio play ''The Rani Reaps the Whirlwind'', and in 2006 she made a guest appearance in the radio comedy series ''[[Nebulous]]''. ===Writing=== {{ISBN|date=August 2011}} O'Mara has written four books, two fictional novels (''When She Was Bad'' and ''Good Time Girl'') and two autobiographical books, ''Vamp Until Ready'' and ''Game Plan: A Woman's Survival Kit''. ==Film and television credits== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Film and television |- !
